answers.author: Mike Cohen
answers.text:
Mary Ann,  
Check-out Peak Democracy Inc's Open Town Hall online public comment platform:  http://www.OpenTownHall.com  .  
Peak Democracy has powered over 700 online public comment forums from over 40 government agencies. These forums have attracted over 70,000 attendees and garnered a user-satisfaction rating of over 96%. 
In comparison to the other services that you mentioned, the key distinguishing benefits of Open Town Hall are that its forums are civil (as online blogs are full of vitriol and misinformation), and legal (in contrast to companies and bloggers, government agencies have legal requirements). The Open Town Hall forums also have great analysis tools and the forums are easy to setup and use. 
The company is an AFI strategic partner -- so AFI members get a 10% discount on pricing. 
Mike (866-535-8894 x701)

answers.author: Lauren Dyson
answers.text:
Hi Mary Ann - we're working on this same question with our new project, Engagement Commons:  http://www.engagementcommons.org 
It's a catalog of tools available to local governments to increase civic engagement, and where they're being used. We're hoping this resource will help cities find new tools to engage their citizens through technology. 
Specifically, you might be interested in these entries to start:  http://civiccommons.org/apps/all-our-ideas-0 
http://civiccommons.org/apps/engagingplans 
http://civiccommons.org/apps/ideascale 
I hope that helps -- let me know if you have any questions. And Engagement Commons is a community-edited wiki, so if you know of any tools that aren't listed, you should add them!

text: I’m interested in the type of technology platform that communities are using to engage their residents. Many of you do outreach with social media but what, if any, technology is used to gather information and provide a forum for discussion, e.g., Basecamp, MindMixer, Granicus.
